intro: Brassica oleracea subsp. gemmifera, commonly known as the cauliflower, is a cool-season crop that belongs to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its dense, compact inflorescence composed of undeveloped flower buds, known as curds. The plant typically grows to a height of 40–80 cm and has dark green, lobed leaves. It thrives in temperate climates and requires a long growing season with consistent moisture. This subspecies is widely cultivated for its edible curds, which are used in various culinary dishes worldwide.
